MBA802.name: Financial Accounting and Reporting Strategy
MBA802.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
MBA802.description: Financial accounting model underlying financial statements of firms. Information in financial statements and role of these statements in capital markets. Information intermediaries, regulators, and role of independent auditor. Standard setting and the impact of changing standards. Globalization of standards.
MBA802.restrictions: Open to MBA students or approval of department.

MBA804.name: Applied Data Analysis for Managers
MBA804.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MBA804.description: Analysis of business and economic data to support managerial decision-making. Building, interpreting, and applying time-series, regression, and forecasting models.
MBA804.restrictions: Open to MBA students or approval of department.

MBA806.name: Social Issues in Management
MBA806.description: Analysis of the business environment including social, ethical, public policy, ecological, and international dimensions. Management of stakeholder relationships.

MBA808.name: Leadership and Teamwork
MBA808.description: Understanding team management and leadership through experiential and skill-based learning. Effective communication, including the use of electronic communication technologies for team development and maintenance. Active practice of teamwork, communication, and leadership skills.

MBA812.name: Accounting for Decision-Making and Control
MBA812.description: The use of accounting information for planning and control. Cost structure and the use of cost analysis, activity-based costing, capacity costing, and cost modeling for improved decision-making. Controlling decisions through budgeting, variance analysis, transfer pricing, financial and non-financial performance measurement, and incentives. Use of the balanced scorecard for assessing strategy implementation.

MBA814.name: Applied Economics
MBA814.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MBA814.description: Economic view of the firm. Use marginal analysis to analyze firms' decisions such as pricing, entry, and price discrimination. Use game theory to analyze firms' strategic behavior, priniciple-agent relationships, adverse selection, and signaling.
MBA814.restrictions: Open to MBA students or approval of department.

MBA816.name: Managerial Communication Strategy and Tactics
MBA816.description: Learning, applying and adapting the basic principles of persuasion and argumentation to oral and written communication in business settings.

MBA817.name: Designing and Delivering Impactful Business Presentations
MBA817.description: Determining relevant presentation content based on audience analysis. Strategic design of content. Oral presentation delivery using PowerPoint as a visual aid. Introduction to effective question and answer methods in business environment.

MBA818.name: Creating Competitive Advantage through Presentations
MBA818.description: Complex business presentations to top business executives and corporate boards. Managing presentation flow and successful completion when facing interruptions and challenges to proposals and findings in real-time presentation settings.

MBA820.name: Marketing Management
MBA820.description: Leadership principles in marketing strategy development. Fundamental marketing concepts such as strategic marketing analysis, market segmentation, targeting, and competitive positioning. Problem-solving and market planning. Application of concepts to case analysis.

MBA821.name: Introduction to Supply Chain Management Concepts
MBA821.description: Integrative approach to understanding supply chain management. Flow of products from concept development through delivery to the final user, including product and process development, managing information, inventory and product flows, and supplier and customer management.

MBA822.name: Corporate Investment Decisions
MBA822.description: Corporate investment decisions including calculation of present value, valuation of bonds and common stock, net present value and other investment criteria, portfolio theory and financial asset pricing models, risk and cost of capital.

MBA823.name: Information Technology Strategy
MBA823.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MBA823.description: Integrative perspectives on the use, management, and economic value of information technologies in organizations. Financial and strategic assessment of the business value of information technologies. Transformational effects of business intelligence and social networking technologies. Technology strategy and entrepreneurship.
MBA823.restrictions: Open to MBA students or approval of department.

MBA824.name: Managing the Workforce
MBA824.description: Role of workforce management in fulfilling the goals and mission of the organization. Theories and applications of management principles to motivating, rewarding, and structuring employees' work; managing groups and teams; and structuring the organization. Domestic and international issues in the workplace.

MBA830.name: Marketing Strategy Execution
MBA830.description: Executing marketing strategy. Using the marketing decision variables to plan and execute in a competitive marketplace. Fundamental marketing topics such as customer satisfaction, customer loyalty and lifetime value, growth strategies, brand value propositions, new product strategies, brand equity development, marketing communication, pricing, channel relationships, internet marketing, and global marketing. Application of course concepts to case analysis.

MBA831.name: Supply Chain Management Applications
MBA831.description: Application of supply chain management concepts. Examining how procurement, logistics and operations management enable value propositions and gain competitive advantage.

MBA832.name: Corporate Financing Decisions
MBA832.description: Corporate financing decisions including efficient markets and behavioral finance, how corporations issue securities, capital structure, shareholder payout policy and agency cost issues.

MBA841.name: Studies in the Global Marketplace
MBA841.description: Commercial, economic, cultural, and political aspects of global environments. Exposure to leading executives and government representatives in world markets. Comparative framework for competitive strategy in a multi-country context. Participation in international field trip required.

MBA843.name: Career Management
MBA843.description: Understanding career development theory through experiential and skill-based learning. Active practice of career management, networking, negotiation, goal setting, and development planning skills.

MBA845.name: Integrative Action Projects
MBA845.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MBA845.description: Multi-day intensive action-based learning experience in which students apply business theories and concepts to real business issues.

MBA846.name: Executive Lecture Series
MBA846.description: CEO perspectives on interdisciplinary business topics. Real-world events and scenarios, global business community, and innovative strategies to manage high-performance organizations.
MBA846.restrictions: Open to MBA students in the The Eli Broad College of Business and open to undergraduate students in the Honors College.

MBA850.name: Strategic Management
MBA850.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MBA850.description: Examines ways top managers create and sustain competitive advantage in today's challenging global marketplace from a total firm perspective.

MBA891.name: Special Topics in Business Management
MBA891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MBA891.description: Current and emerging issues in management. New and changing developments affecting managers.

MBA893.name: MBA Internship Experience
MBA893.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MBA893.description: Internship in business organizations; application of business knowledge and management techniques in a work environment.
MBA893.restrictions: Open to MBA students and not open to students in the Master of Business Administration in Integrative Management.
